abstract: Whatever the outcome of Microsoft’s bid for Yahoo, the move and Google’s countermoves mark  an escalation in the confrontation between the two companies.
snippet: Whatever the outcome of Microsoft’s bid for Yahoo, the move and Google’s countermoves mark  an escalation in the confrontation between the two companies.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title “Only the Paranoid Survive.”

headline.main: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid
headline.print_headline: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid

abstract: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title “Only the Paranoid Survive.”
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title “Only the Paranoid Survive.”

headline.main: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid

abstract: The prospect of working for Steven Ballmer and the leviathan that is Microsoft can’t help but be a bit distracting to the many employees of Yahoo. That could be why Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive of Yahoo, decided to circulate a memo to his workers Wednesday in which he thanked them for “staying focused on executing our priorities” and asked them to sit tight while Yahoo considers how to respond to Microsoft’s $44.6 billion takeover offer.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of working for Steven Ballmer and the leviathan that is Microsoft can’t help but be a bit distracting to the many employees of Yahoo. That could be why Jerry Yang, the co-founder and chief executive of Yahoo, decided to circulate a memo to his workers Wednesday in which he thanked them for “staying focused on executing our priorities” and asked them to sit tight while Yahoo considers how to respond to Microsoft’s $44.6 billion takeover offer.

headline.main: Yang to Yahoos: Don’t Lose Focus

abstract: Time Warner hopes that separating the Internet access business will make it easier to sell, spin out, or form partnerships with the rest of AOL. But since the Microsoft-Yahoo combination eliminates two possible partners, and AOL’s business is stagnant, it may have to go it alone.
snippet: Time Warner hopes that separating the Internet access business will make it easier to sell, spin out, or form partnerships with the rest of AOL. But since the Microsoft-Yahoo combination eliminates two possible partners, and AOL’s business is stag...
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of optimism about AOL from Jeff Bewkes this morning on his first conference call as chief executive of Time Warner, probably more than is appropriate given the likely combination of Yahoo and Microsoft.
